Recent research progress of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) based catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition reaction Shuo Yan Weizuo Li ⁎ Dafang He Guangyu He Haiqun Chen ⁎ Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Advanced Catalysis and Green Manufacturing Collaborative Innovation Center, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, Jiangsu, 213000, China Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Advanced Catalysis and Green Manufacturing Collaborative Innovation Center, School of Petrochemical Engineering Changzhou University Changzhou Jiangsu 213000 China Key Laboratory of Advanced Catalytic Materials and Technology, Advanced Catalysis and Green Manufacturing Collaborative Innovation Center, School of Petrochemical Engineering, Changzhou University, Changzhou, Jiangsu, 213000, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The combustion of fossil fuels leads to the significant emission of carbonaceous compounds (e.g. CO2, CO), which results in a range of environmental problems (e.g. global warming). Among numerous carbonaceous compounds, although CO2 is the main culprit causing greenhouse effect, it is also an important carbon resource that can be used as a raw material for the synthesis of other important chemical substances. Among numerous CO2 activation and conversion processes, CO2 cycloaddition is an economically efficient transformation method because of its low price of raw materials, no other by-products during the reaction process, and atomic utilization rate of up to 100%, which comply with "green chemistry" and "atom economy". Moreover, the products of cyclic carbonates (e.g. ethylene carbonate, propylene carbonate) play a crucial role in the electric vehicle industry and are widely utilized for their numerous advantages. However, CO2 is inert and difficult to be activated, so the search for efficient and stable catalysts is crucial for the rapid CO2 conversion. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as highly promising materials in the field of CO2 activation and conversion due to their tremendous potential for development. This review provides a comprehensive analysis of the application of MOFs based catalysts in CO2 conversion. In addition, this study explores potential techniques for enhancing the catalytic efficiency of novel catalysts based on MOFs while investigating unexplored reactions for CO2 conversion. Graphical abstract Application of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs)-based catalysts for the direct conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) to cyclic carbonate. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Carbon dioxide metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) cyclic carbonates CO2 cycloaddition Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction 1.1 Current status of catalytic conversion research of CO2 With the continuous progress of society and the development of industrial technology, human demand for energy is increasing [1–3]. The combustion of large amounts of fossil fuels has resulted in a continual increase in atmospheric CO2 concentration. The high concentrations of CO2 in the air causes a series of global warming and environmental problems (such as rising surface temperature), which seriously threatens human activities and survival [4]. The implementation of CO2 capture and storage (abbreviated as CCS) and CO2 capture and utilization (abbreviated as CCU) technologies is anticipated to become key strategies for mitigating greenhouse gas emissions and decreasing dependence on fossil resources. The difference between them is that the final use of the captured CO2 is different. The CCS technology contains the separation of CO2 from industrial or other emission sources, after which the captured CO2 is transported to storage sites where it is securely isolated from the atmosphere for a significant duration. Moreover, the CCU technology aims to utilize the captured CO2 by converting it into high-value commercial products [5]. While CCS and CCU technologies offer potential solutions for mitigating global warming and addressing environmental degradation, they also come with certain drawbacks. One significant drawback is the substantial energy consumption associated with various stages of the process, including separation, purification, compression, transportation, and storage [6,7]. This energy consumption is likely to result in more CO2 emissions. These problems hinder the industrial application of CCS. The CCU technology uses CO2 as a renewable carbon raw material and converts it into usable chemicals and fuels to replace fossil resources. Therefore, the implementation of CCU technology has the potential to make a valuable contribution towards reducing CO2 emissions and diminishing reliance on fossil resources. 1.2 Catalytic transformation reactions involving CO2 From an economic perspective, CO2 has significant advantages such as being non-toxic, easy to store and transport, abundant in raw materials, and inexpensive to prepare compared to other toxic, difficult to obtain or transport chemical reagents [8–10]. Therefore, various chemical products can be obtained by using CO2 as a feedstock [11,12] (Fig. 1 ): 1) catalytic hydrogenation reaction can be used to synthesize methane, formic acid [13,14], low-carbon olefins, and dimethyl ether; 2) Participating in the ring-opening reaction of epoxides, CCU technology can be utilized to prepare cyclic carbonates.; 3) Methanol and its deep processing products are finally generated by methane reforming; 4) Salicylic acid is synthesized by carbonylation. However, the carbon atom in CO2 exists in a tetravalent state and exhibits stable thermodynamic properties, which presents challenges in terms of activation. Currently, there are several strategies to achieve CO2 conversion: 1) Use high-activity raw molecules to react with CO2, including hydrogen, unsaturated compounds or metal organic compounds; 2) Synthesize some low-energy target product molecules, such as organic carbonates, etc.; 3) Design suitable chemical reaction processes to move the equilibrium toward the product direction by separating the main product; 4) Introduce additional energy, such as light energy, electrical energy, etc., to trigger chemical reactions; 5) Introduce efficient catalysts to reduce reaction barriers [15]. In the past few decades, scientists have developed many catalytic materials for CO2 catalytic conversion, examples of materials that have been explored for CO2 activation include ionic liquids (ILs) [16,17], zeolites [18–21], porous carbons [22–25], metal complexes [26,27], porous organic polymers (POP) [28–30], covalent-organic frameworks (COFs) [31–33], as well as MOFs [7,34-36]. Although there is much research on CO2 chemical conversion, most of them are costly and lack effective and feasible solutions, which restrict their commercial application, so most of them are still in the research stage. Currently, in the methods of synthesizing industrial products using CO2 as a feedstock, most of them that can be industrialized are methanol [37–39], urea [40], salicylic acid [41], CO2 participating in ring-opening reaction to synthesize cyclic carbonates [42,43], and polycarbonates [44,45]. However, other CO2 fixation technologies are still in the laboratory research stage. 1.3 Applications of CO2 in cycloaddition reactions Cyclic carbonates are highly valued for their exceptional properties (e.g. solubility, high boiling points), which make them versatile in a wide range of applications [46,47]. Moreover, cyclic carbonates are utilized as chemical precursors for the production of various chemicals (including phenolic resins, polycarbonates) [48]. The methods for synthesizing cyclic carbonates mainly include phosgene method, ester exchange method, and CO2 carbonylation to epoxides (Fig. 2 ). In the 19th century, researchers synthesized propylene carbonate (PC) from phosgene (COCl2) and propylene glycol. However, this production process used highly toxic COCl2, and the byproduct, hydrogen chloride, was strongly corrosive. It not only required high equipment demands but also had poor safety and caused environmental pollution [49]. This practice was inconsistent with the strategic objectives towards sustainable development and green chemistry, and has since been discontinued. The use of diols and linear carbonates to prepare cyclic carbonates through ester exchange resulted in low yield and selectivity, difficult product purification, and high cost. Compared to COCl2, CO2 exhibits unparalleled characteristics (e.g. inexpensive, non-toxic) as a ring-closing reagent. Utilizing CO2 as a feedstock for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates is a significant approach in the utilization of CO2 resources (Fig. 3 ) [50–53]. When using CO2 instead of COCl2 to react with diols such as ethylene glycol and propylene glycol to prepare cyclic carbonates, the product yield is low due to limited thermodynamic balance and water generation during the reaction process, which causes catalyst deactivation [54,55]. The process of using CO2 and chloropropanol to prepare cyclic carbonates generates chlorine gas during the reaction process, which requires high equipment demands and complicated post-treatment processes. The use of CO2 and olefins for direct oxidation carbonylation to prepare cyclic carbonates is widely regarded due to low-cost raw materials and avoidance of using epoxides, etc [56,57]. However, this process often requires expensive oxidants, produces low product yields, and generates a large number of byproducts such as aldehydes and acids, leading to difficulties in product purification. Alcohols or olefins are important substrates used in the synthesis of cyclic carbonates through the reaction with CO2. However, the current development mode is still at the laboratory stage. However, compared to other production processes, using epoxides (e.g. ethylene oxide, epoxypropane) and CO2 for cycloaddition reactions in the production of cyclic carbonates offers several advantages. These include the availability of inexpensive raw materials, a reduced production of byproducts, and a high utilization of atoms, all of which align with the principles of sustainable development. It is also one of the few ways to achieve industrial applications of CO2 [58,59]. At present, large-scale synthesis of cyclic carbonates (e.g. ethylene carbonate) using CO2 as the feedstock is carried out in kettle-type reactors. This process involves the use of catalysts such as alkali metal halides [60], quaternary ammonium salts [61], among others. However, these catalysts have poor solubility in epoxides, requiring the addition of large amounts of solvents, and only show high activity at high temperatures and pressures, with a large amount of by-products formation and a complex product purification process. Moreover, the mutual solubility between the reaction products and the catalysts makes catalyst recovery difficult. To date, numerous homogeneous catalysts, such as metal halides [62], ILs [63,64], organic bases [65], and metal complexes [66–68], have been designed and synthesized for catalyzing the preparation of cyclic carbonates through CO2 cycloaddition reactions. Additionally, various heterogeneous catalysts, including supported metal oxides [69], polymerized ionic liquid-supported catalysts [70–72], MOFs [73–75], as well as MOFs derived catalysts [76], have also been employed for CO2 cycloaddition reactions. 2 Research progress in MOFs materials for cyclic carbonates 2.1 Characteristics of MOFs based materials MOFs are a class of crystalline materials characterized by their porous structure [77–79]. Currently, over 20,000 types of MOFs materials have been designed and synthesized through employing different metals and organic ligands, showcasing their immense potential across various fields [80,81]. In MOFs, the dominant form of bonding occurs through the coordination between metal centers and organic ligands. However, other binding forces, including hydrogen bonds, van der Waals forces, and π-π stacking, also contribute to the overall structure of the prepared MOFs. MOFs materials exhibit several unique characteristics, including ultra-low mass density, large pore volume, and a customizable pore size distribution (Fig. 4 ) [82]. Isoreticular metal-organic frameworks (IRMOFs) consist primarily of a repeating network topology structure formed by [Zn4O6]+ metal clusters and carboxylic acid-based organic ligands [83–85]. IRMOFs possess a relatively large cavity and pore volume. Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), on the other hand, synthesized by a self-assembly process between the metal nodes (Zn or Co) and imidazole ligand forming a tetrahedral coordination mode [86–88]. The pore structure of ZIFs closely resembles that of silica aluminosilicate zeolites. ZIFs boast high porosity, modifiable organic linking groups, and metal centers. Moreover, compared with other MOFs, ZIFs have better thermal stability and chemical stability. Metarial sofistitute lavoisier frameworks (MILs) is another special type of MOFs material, which can be formed by coordinating three-valent transition metal ions (such as Fe3+, Al3+, Cr3+) with carboxylic acid ligands [89–91]. The structure of Ocket-channel frameworks (PCNs) is more complex. HKUST-1 is a typical PCN, which is formed by coordinating Cu2(COO)4 clusters with trimesic acid, and has two pore structures [92,93]. One is the orthogonal pore, and the other is the straight three-dimensional orthogonal channel. In the past decade, researchers have used various methods to prepare MOFs, such as room-temperature solution method [94], hydrothermal method [95], diffusion method [96], microwave-assisted method [97,98], ultrasonic synthesis method [99], mechanochemical synthesis method [100], and electrochemistry [101]. The main distinction between these approaches lies in the form of energy input, and the resulting MOFs often exhibit the following characteristics: 1) Structural designability: MOFs have the ability to incorporate highly reactive Lewis acid-base pairs within a single material. 2) Structural diversity: Reacting different metal centers with various ligands allows for preparation of novel structures. 3) Pore accessibility: MOFs can effectively confine guest components (e.g. metal nanoparticles, metal oxides), enabling them to exploit their respective advantages. 4) Modifiability of organic ligand groups: The ligands can be functionalized and subsequently utilized in the synthesis of MOFs, or the functional groups within reported MOFs can undergo covalent modifications. 5) Some MOFs can be thermally decomposed to enhance the material's thermal stability and chemical stability, and MOFs thermally decomposed in a porous carbon matrix can produce metal/metal oxide nanoparticles with uniform distribution of active sites, thus achieving efficient catalytic conversion in various catalytic reactions. These features provide functional MOFs with broader application prospects. 2.2 Research progress on the utilization of MOFs materials in CO2 cycloaddition reactions MOFs offer several advantages, including a high surface area, exceptional adsorption capabilities, controllable and customizable pore structures, and active sites that serve to enhance the interaction between MOFs and CO2 molecules. These properties enable MOFs to facilitate gas enrichment as catalytic active sites for the reaction with CO2 [102–104]. As heterogeneous catalysts, MOFs have unique advantages: 1) their functionalized pores can be used for substrate sieving; 2) the uniformly distributed metal centers can act as active catalytic centers; 3) Furthermore, MOFs offer the advantage of easy recoverability and reusability. These include propylene carbonate, urea, acrylic acid, and benzene carboxylic acid. The reaction mechanism of CO2 cycloaddition involves the activation of epoxides through coordinatively unsaturated metal/metal clusters. This activation leads to the formation of alcohol salt intermediates. Moreover, MOFs possess Lewis basic sites with high electron cloud density that facilitate the activation of CO2, bringing it to an activated state. These activated CO2 molecules then combine with the alcohol salt intermediates, resulting in the formation of final product of cyclic carbonates (Fig. 5 ) [105]. Using MOFs as the catalyst for this reaction not only has a higher yield but also has special advantages in comparison with other materials: 1) In certain MOFs materials, The removal of guest molecules that coordinate axially in the inorganic secondary building units exposes open metal sites. These open metal sites served as Lewis acid sites could participate in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction; 2) modified organic ligands (such as urea groups, triazole groups, etc.), which usually have high electron cloud density and are suitable Lewis basic sites that can effectively accelerate the reaction; 3) The large size of nanopore and ultra-high specific surface area of MOFs facilitate the accumulation of reactants (epoxides and CO2) near the catalytic active sites, enhancing their participation in the reaction. Moreover, the generated products can diffuse freely within the MOF structure, which improves catalytic efficiency; 4) MOFs are a type of heterogeneous catalyst that can be separated from the system through relatively simple processing methods after the reaction. All of characteristics demonstrate the superior suitability of MOFs could be chosen as highly efficient catalysts for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. To ensure the performance of MOFs catalysts in reactions and maximize the utilization of Lewis acid sites on metal centers, researchers typically remove impurities present on the surface of catalyst and within its pores, as well as weakly coordinated solvent molecules on secondary building units. This activation step has a significant role in improving the performance of as-prepared MOFs catalysts for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. This is usually achieved by exchanging high-boiling point coordinating solvents with low-boiling point solvents or by generating Lewis acid sites by removing coordinating unsaturated sites through vacuum pumping [106]. When laboratory conditions permit, MOFs can also be activated using supercritical CO2 with high solubility, which is a mild process that does not damage the structure of MOFs [107]. Moreover, the performance of MOFs catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition reaction could be improved through by using the modified organic ligands, or encapsulation of active guests within the pores. 2.2.1 Imidazole based MOFs for CO2 cycloaddition reactions Porous materials, especially for MOFs, containing nitrogen-containing ligands exhibit a strong affinity for CO2. One such class of MOFs is ZIFs, which exhibits a structure similar to zeolites synthesized by reacting Zn2+ or Co2+ ions with imidazole ligands. In comparison to zeolite molecular sieves, ZIFs offer a wider range of pore structures, some of which are not found in traditional zeolites. ZIFs have attracted significant interest in the fields of materials science and catalysis due to their exceptional properties (e.g. high thermal and chemical stability, impressive porosity) [108–110]. For instance, ZIF-8, comprised of 2-methylimidazole (2-mIM) and Zn2+ ions, has emerged as a prominent research focus due to its impressive stability and molecular sieve properties. ZIFs possess bifunctional sites (Lewis acid and Lewis base), which consist of coordinatively unsaturated Zn2+ or Co2+ ions and imidazole-type ligands. The presence of bifunctional sites promotes the efficient adsorption and activation of CO2, reducing the energy barrier and demonstrating high catalytic activity in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. Lin et al. successfully synthesized hexagonal ZIF-78 crystals (hereafter referred to as ZIF-78) through a hydrothermal method, combining Zn with an imidazolate ester skeleton (Fig. 6a ). ZIF-78 was subsequently applied for the CO2 cycloaddition and propylene oxide (PO). In comparison to other ZIF-based catalysts, the prepared hexagonal crystals of ZIF-78 demonstrate exceptional CO2 adsorption capacity, which can be attributed to the strong interaction between the nitro functional (-NO2) group and CO2 reactant molecules. Additionally, ZIF-78 possesses dual functionality sites (Lewis acid site of Zn atom, and Lewis base site of -NH group). This dual functionality enables ZIF-78 MOFs to efficiently catalyze the CO2 cycloaddition process and PO without extra co-catalysts or solvents. The 54% yield of PC was achieved under a certain reaction conditions (150°C, 0.98 MPa, and 15 h) [111]. Multi-metallic organic frameworks materials, which contain more than one metal in MOFs materials, usually have multiple metals combined with each other, but the ligands are generally only one type. Due to the possible synergistic effects of two or more metals, multi-metal MOFs materials exhibit better catalytic performance than single-metal MOFs. Tang et al. introduced a porous bimetallic catalyst by the modified structure of MOFs nanoparticles through cation exchange reactions, as well as Kirkendall effect. Through cation exchange with Au3+ ions, the ZIF-8 nanoparticles were transformed into Au/Zn-MOF nano-cages (Fig. 6e) resulting from the presence of active sites. The Au/Zn-MOF catalyst exhibits excellent performance (99% yield of cyclic carbonates) for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction under mild reaction conditions. This nanomaterial offers several advantages (e.g. simple preparation, multiple active sites), making it a promising catalyst for CO2 conversion [112]. Xu et al. used entropy-driven room-temperature mechanical chemical method to synthesize high-entropy zeolite-imidazole frameworks (HE-ZIFs) (Fig. 6b). HE-ZIFs is a unique MOFs that incorporates five different metal ions (Zn2+, Co2+, Cd2+, Ni2+, and Cu2+). In contrast to ZIF-8, HE-ZIF demonstrates excellent performance in CO2 cycloaddition reaction. This heightened activity may be attributed to the synergistic effect between the Zn2+, Co2+, Cd2+, Ni2+ and Cu2+ ions, which act as Lewis acid sites and facilitate the activation of epoxides [113]. The deliberate design and careful selection of organic ligands and metal clusters, each with distinct structures and active sites, are critical in the advancement of MOFs materials. Recently, incorporating two organic ligands with distinct active sites into MOFs has been a subject of extensive research. This approach offers several advantages, including increased coordination modes and the integration of multiple active sites within the framework. Nguyen et al. synthesized amino-functionalized bimetallic ZIF-8 (Co/Zn-ZIF-A) (Fig. 6c) through an auxiliary ligand exchange (3-amino-1,2,4-triazole, termed as Atz) for CO2 cycloaddition reaction. By adjusting the exchange reaction time of 2-mIM and Atz, the ammonia content in the Co/Zn-ZIF-A material could be controlled. The study revealed that a 24 h exchange yielded the highest ammonia content, and the developed catalyst (Co/Zn-ZIF-A) achieved a conversion rate and selectivity of epichlorohydrin of 99% without the need for a co-catalyst or solvent (at 80°C and 0.1 Mpa CO2). For Co/Zn-ZIF-A, the acid-base cooperative effect between metal nodes (Zn and Co) and functional groups (-NH2 and -NH) could efficiently enhance the catalytic performance in CO2 cycloaddition reaction. The Co/Zn-ZIF-A catalyst demonstrated no significant decrease in activity over five cycles and exhibited excellent repeatability [114]. Moreover, a novel MOF called Zn-NDC (Fig. 6d), using a triazole ligand with multiple chelating amine sites and zinc perchlorate has been synthesized. Using the triazole ligand containing chelating amine sites and triazole functional groups could enrich the coordination modes and improve the adsorption ability of CO2 during the reaction process [115]. 2.2.2 Carboxylic acid based MOFs for CO2 cycloaddition reaction Carboxylic acid-based MOFs represent one of the earliest discovered categories of MOFs and have consistently exhibited exceptional catalytic performance in CO2 cycloaddition reactions. In terms of morphology and structure, carboxylic functional groups exhibit strong coordination abilities and can form framework structures with various types of metal ions (from divalent to tetravalent). Furthermore, based on hard and soft acid-base theory, carboxylic ligands can establish highly stable MOFs structures with metal ions, particularly those of high valence [116]. Thermal treatment of carboxylic acid-based MOFs leads to the formation of highly porous graphitic structures, significantly enhancing the diversity of composition, structure, and functionality of carboxylic acid-based MOFs derivatives. Defective sites within MOFs materials can serve as active sites for facilitating CO2 cycloaddition reactions. Xiang et al. developed a straightforward and energy-efficient method utilizing Ar plasma treatment under atmospheric pressure, at temperatures lower than 125°C, and without the use of harmful chemicals. This treatment induced ligand defects while maintaining the stability of UiO-66 (Fig. 7a ). The high-energy argon plasma decomposed certain organic ligands in UiO-66, thereby generating unsaturated Zr sites. The content of defects in UiO-66 has a certain relationship with the duration of plasma bombardment. After 0.5 h treatment, the number of defects per Zr6 metal-cluster reached 2.3. UiO-66 with a substantial number of ligand defects exhibited a catalytic yield approximately 43% higher than that of pristine UiO-66. This confirms the pivotal role of ligand defects could improve catalytic activity of UiO-66 during reaction process. This approach of creating ligand defects holds promise for application in other types of MOF-based catalysts and diverse fields [117]. Gao et al. successfully synthesized a bimetallic MOFs (Zn/Mg-MOF-74) by using a one-pot method (Fig. 7b). The optimized Zn0.75Mg0.25-MOF-74 exhibited remarkable CO2 adsorption capacity (128.3 cm3·g−1), along with excellent performance in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction (solvent-free, 60°C, 0.8 Mpa). The catalytic conversion and selectivity of Zn0.75Mg0.25-MOF-74 for the reaction exceeded 99%, surpassing those achieved by the common catalyst towards prepared by the physical mixing method (Zn-MOF-74 mixed with Mg-MOF-74). The catalytic results have revealed that synergistic effect between the Zn and Mg contained in Zn0.75Mg0.25-MOF-74. This study demonstrates that bimetallic node MOFs are superior to single metal node MOFs in terms of CO2 adsorption and catalytic conversion [118]. The double ligand strategy can provide a unique pillar-layer structure that has better structural stability with coordinated pillar connections. Tapiador et al. synthesized a novel MOFs containing 2-aminoterephthalic acid (3-amino-1,2,4-triazole) and 4,4-bipyridyl ligands (named as Cu-URJC-8) (Fig. 7d). The Cu-URJC-8 is a columnar layered structure composed of paddle-shaped [Cu2(-CO2)4(-N)2] units, where 4,4-bipyridyl ligands act as pillars in a doubly interpenetrated network, providing a sturdy structure for the material. The synthesized Cu-URJC-8 MOFs possess both Lewis acid-base sites (Cu2+ and -NH2, respectively), enabling effective catalysis in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. Reaction cycle tests have confirmed the catalyst's high stability concerning both structural integrity and catalytic activity [119]. Compared with only using the open metal sites (as Lewis acid sites) contained in MOFs to catalyze CO2 cycloaddition reactions, the synergy of introducing functional groups with high electron density (such as amino groups, urea groups, acylamide groups, etc.) as Lewis basic sites in organic ligands and combined with open metal sites to catalyze the reaction has attracted significant attention. The presence of multiple active sites can have a "1 + 1> 2" effect in promoting CO2 cycloaddition reactions. Li et al. successfully constructed MOFs with rich N-based groups and unsaturated coordinating sites by self-assembling four-carboxylic acid ligands containing acylamide groups and Cu2+ ions, {Cu2[(C20H12N2O2)(COO)4]}n (Fig. 7c). The prepared MOFs exhibit a combination of high porosity and significant CO2 adsorption capacity. Subsequent studies have revealed that the catalyst displays high catalytic efficiency for CO2 and small molecule substrates, such as epichlorohydrin, in cycloaddition reactions. However, the catalytic activity decreases significantly when the reaction involves larger molecule substrates, suggesting that the catalyst demonstrates a high degree of selectivity based on substrate size [120]. Wang et al. synthesized a novel type of MOFs, {[Co2(tzpa)(OH)(H2O)2]·DMF}n, with one-dimensional tubular channels containing open metal sites by using a 5-(4-(tetrazol-5-yl)phenyl)isophthalic acid ligand containing carboxyl and tetrazole groups (Fig. 7e). The catalytic results demonstrated that the {[Co2(tzpa)(OH)(H2O)2]·DMF}n exhibited excellent performance (93.8% yield) as well as good recyclability for the CO2 cycloaddition reaction under the mild reaction conditions (25°C, and 0.1 MPa CO2) [121]. 2.2.3 Other MOFs used in CO2 cycloaddition reactions Salen primarily refers to a class of organic compounds that contain imine or methylimine functional groups (-RC=N-). Salen is generally synthesized from the condensation of an amine and an active carbonyl compound and is used as an organic synthetic reagent and liquid crystal material. When Salen is complexed with a metal, the resulting metal-Salen has strong coordination ability. In recent years, many researchers have introduced metal-Salen organic ligands into MOFs materials to enhance performance for CO2 cycloaddition reactions. The Fan group successfully constructed a Cd-MOFs material (Fig. 8a ) by using a Ni-Salen-containing ligand. The catalytic activity centers in this material, such as the Ni-Salen and open metal sites, impart excellent CO2 cycloaddition reaction catalytic activity [122]. Subsequently, the group synthesized four compounds by introducing metal-Salen ligands into UiO-type Zr-MOFs (Fig. 8b), which also demonstrated higher catalytic performance than ordinary UiO-type Zr-MOFs ligands [123]. Porphyrin is a large molecular heterocyclic compound formed by four pyrrole subunits linked by a meso-methylene bridge (=CH-). Porphyrin and its derivatives are common ligands for synthesizing MOFs materials and have excellent visible light absorption properties, undergoing electron transfer and energy transfer under light conditions. Researchers have extensively explored CO2 cycloaddition reactions using porphyrin-MOFs based on this characteristic. Nagaraja et al. synthesized an example of Mn-porphyrin MOFs (Fig. 8c), in which the electron and energy transfer produced by light increased the catalytic activity of Mn-MOF. The catalytic performance (TON, TOF) were nearly doubled compared to the reaction condition without light [124]. Huang et al. introduced Bi into the structure of the porphyrin MOFs (PCN-224) (Fig. 8d), which, combined with the light activation of CO2 molecules, effectively reduced the energy barrier of the subsequent reaction process and greatly improved the catalytic performance of the MOFs material. This provided an economically effective method for MOFs to catalyze CO2 cycloaddition reactions under mild conditions [125]. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are a class of excellent metal-oxygen anion clusters composed of highly oxidized early transition metals. Due to their excellent structural properties, outstanding thermal stability, tunable light absorption ability, and well-defined active sites, POMs have attracted increasing attention in CO2 photocatalysis area. Zhou et al. designed a heterogeneous catalyst (PBPCT*) towards ionic polymers (IPs) and phosphomolybdate (PMo12) co-modified CuTCPPCo MOF. This catalyst can efficiently convert CO2 under mild conditions without the need for solvents or co-catalysts, utilizing solar energy as the driving force (Fig. 9a ) [126]. This is because the introduction of POMs and IPs changes the band structure of the PBPCT* catalyst, optimizes the heterojunction, enhances the reduction ability of electrons, promotes the transfer of photo-generated electrons from the catalyst to the reactant, thereby facilitating the occurrence of the photocatalytic CO2 and epoxide ring cycloaddition reaction. Fang et al. synthesized phosphomolybdate-modified ferrocene-based Zr-Fc (PMo12@Zr-Fc) nanosheets with excellent photothermal conversion capabilities (Fig. 9b). These nanosheets can effectively catalyze the conversion of CO2 under light stimulation. Specifically, the molecular dispersion of PMo12 on the Zr-Fc nanosheets greatly enhances the catalytic activity [127]. ILs composed of organic cations and organic or inorganic anions have advantages such as high catalytic performance, strong designability, and environmental friendliness. They are widely used as a new type of green catalyst in the catalytic CO2 cycloaddition reaction. However, as high-viscosity homogeneous catalysts, it is difficult to separate ILs from catalytic systems, which limits their practical applications. One effective method to address this issue is to immobilize ILs onto porous materials such as MOFs [68]. Zhong et al. synthesized catalysts containing multiple active sites, IL@ZIF-8 (Zn/Co), using a solvent-free mechanochemical synthesis method [128]. The research findings revealed that the introduction of Co2+ and ILs is beneficial for enhancing the catalytic performance of MOFs catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition reaction (Fig. 9c). Xiao et al. prepared imidazole-based ILs functionalized UiO-66-NH2 (SP@UiO-66-NH2 and CB@UiO-66-NH2) using two methods: acylation reaction and the interaction between H2N- and HSO3 − [129] (Fig. 9d). CB@UiO-66-NH2, which has more ionic liquid grafting through the interaction between H2N- and HSO3 −, exhibits higher catalytic performance. The yield of chloroethyl carbonate was 96.4% when the reaction was conducted at a temperature of 95 °C, CO2 pressure of 2.5 MPa, and for a duration of 8 h. Moreover, there have been many reports focused on using MOFs as carriers to support metal oxides [92], non-metal oxides [130], and high-molecular-weight polymers [131] for catalyzing CO2 cycloaddition reactions. These studies on performance of MOFs in CO2 cycloaddition provide new ideas for subsequent research and are of great significance. In addition, as shown in Table 1 , we also compare the differences towards catalytic performance of MOFs with various structures and catalysts prepared on them as carriers in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. 3 Research progress on MOFs derived materials for CO2 cycloaddition reaction 3.1 Characterization of MOFs derived catalysts Recently, post-treatment of MOFs, especially high-temperature pyrolysis, can convert them into advanced functionalized materials. MOFs contain both metal and organic sources and are ideal precursors for preparing functionalized composite materials. Furthermore, MOFs can also function as templates for regulating the morphology and structure of the resulting the specific catalysts. The MOFs derived nanomaterials by thermal treatment usually have the following advantages: 1) Organic ligands containing elements such as nitrogen, oxygen, sulfur, and phosphorus can be directly integrated into the carbon framework of MOFs. This integration serves two purposes: first, it provides abundant catalytic active sites, and second, it creates a favorable environment for the growth of functional nanometer particles [132,133]. Additionally, metal ions within MOFs can be transformed into corresponding metal monomers or compounds, ensuring their uniform distribution within the carbon framework [134]. By carefully adjusting the synthesis conditions, materials with favorable morphology can be obtained [135]. Furthermore, MOFs derived materials inherit the remarkable properties of their precursor MOFs (e.g. large surface area, high porosity) [136]. Carbon-based materials are highly sought after for their good properties (e.g. high surface area, good conductivity), making them ideal for diverse applications in fields like environmental remediation, energy storage systems, catalysts, drug delivery, and many others. Typically, carbon-based materials are produced through the carbonization of organic precursors. To overcome limitations (e.g. disordered, uncertain chemical composition) of carbonization of organic precursors, ordered porous carbon-based materials are commonly synthesized using hard templates, such as mesoporous silica (e.g., MCM-41, KCC-1), and zeolites, which impart a well-defined and regular porous structure to the final material. The synthesis steps of the hard template method typically include the preparation of the initial template, filling with the organic precursor, pyrolysis, and template removal. Moreover, certain doping processes may require some hazardous chemical treatments, which seriously hinder their large-scale production and further applications. Recently, utilizing MOFs as precursors for the preparation of nanoporous carbon based materials has been growing interest. Based on the specific MOFs precursors employed, MOFs derived carbon-based materials could be categorized into three distinct groups. The first category involves the direct pyrolysis of MOFs precursors to produce porous carbon-based materials [137,138]. The second category involves the synthesis of porous carbon-based materials by combining MOFs with heteroatom sources [139–141]. Lastly, the third category entails the preparation of carbon-based materials using MOFs/X composites (X = CNT, rGO, and Te) [142]. The physical-chemical properties of derived materials are influenced by their structure and composition. Materials with hollow structures possess distinct characteristics (e.g. low density, microreactor environments, and increased loading capacity). Therefore, the utilization of hollow structured materials has garnered considerable attention in many technological applications (e.g. electrochemical energy storage [143,144], photocatalysis and/or electrocatalysis [145], drug delivery systems [146], chemical adsorption [147], and sensor technology [148,149]). Hollow materials derived from MOFs offer a wide range of structural complexities, allowing for adjustable pore size, diverse morphology, multilevel/multishell structures, and internal pores/passages. 3.2 Application of MOFs derived catalysts in CO2 cycloaddition reactions 3.2.1 Imidazole derived MOFs based catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition reactions ZIFs materials have been widely utilized as precursors for the synthesis of carbon-based catalysts due to their simple structure and adjustable morphology. Among them, ZIF-8 based MOFs derived materials have garnered significant interest due to their high nitrogen content and specific surface area. Ma et al. employed a grinding method to synthesize several ZIF-derived porous carbon materials, specifically NPC-900 (Fig. 10a ), encapsulating ZnO and/or Co metal particles. The optimized NPC-900 composite material exhibits a layered porous structure, high specific surface area (548 m2·g−1), moderate CO2 adsorption capacity (41 cm3·g−1), and a rich abundance of catalytic active sites, which responsible for good performance of NPC-900 in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. The inclusion of magnetic Co particles allows for the simple recovery of NPC-900 by using an external magnet. Notably, the NPC-900 is capable of maintaining its functionality even when exposed to water treatment and low concentrations of CO2 (15%). Additionally, the authors investigated the photo-thermal effect of NPC-900 in solar-driven CO2 chemical fixation. Under light irradiation, NPC-900 facilitates the efficient conversion of CO2 into corresponding cyclic carbonates [76]. Yang et al. designed a catalyst (termed as ZnO/NCO-L) with multiple active sites derived from the thermolysis and oxidation treatment of Zn-ZIF-L precursor (Fig. 10b). The ZnO/NCO-L catalyst exhibits high dispersion of ZnO nanoparticles and more pyridinic nitrogen, providing rich reaction Lewis acid-base sites for CO2 cycloaddition. The Zn-ZIF-L catalyst demonstrates high performance for CO2 cycloaddition under mild conditions (70°C, and 0.1 MPa CO2) [150]. Guo et al. proposed a restricted pyrolysis method for synthesizing single Zn atom nitrogen-doped hierarchical-ordered porous carbon polyhedra (Zn-N-HOPCPs) (Fig. 11a ). In this approach, single crystal ZIFs are pyrolyzed within SiO2 colloid crystal templates to produce single-atom catalysts derived from ZIFs. This method preserves the original single crystal morphology and creates an organized large pore structure, facilitating the formation of high single Zn atom loading. The Zn-N-HOPCPs possess Lewis acid sites in the form of Zn and basic sites (pyridine N). Additionally, the high surface area of 1128 m2·g−1, large pore volume of 0.90 cm3·g−1, high Zn content of 5.8 wt%, periodically connected pore windows (∼55 nm), as well as highly accessible micro/mesoporous channels (0.55, 0.8, 1.2 and 4 nm) endow the Zn-N-HOPCPs catalyst exhibited high catalytic performance for CO2 cycloaddition. Moreover, the Zn-N-HOPCPs also demonstrate a broad range of light responses (from 230 to 800 nm), encompassing nearly the ultraviolet to visible light spectra of solar radiation. Exploiting these advantages, the Zn-N-HOPCPs were employed as catalysts, in combination with tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) as a co-catalyst, at room temperature and pressure. By utilizing CO2 and propylene oxide as raw materials, cyclic carbonate was synthesized as a model reaction, with a remarkable catalytic yield of 95%. Furthermore, the developed Zn-N-HOPCPs catalyst exhibited outstanding catalytic performance in the cyclization of other cyclic substrates containing epoxy groups and large molecular sizes attributed to the ordered large pore structure, mesoporous features, and microporous architecture. All of these facilitate efficient mass transfer of CO2 and epoxides while enhancing the exposure of internal active sites [151]. This preparation strategy shows potential for creating a new pathway towards the development of efficient MOFs-based materials and their derivative catalytic systems. The prepared hierarchical-ordered porous single-atom catalysts have broad application potential in chemical adsorption/separation, energy storage and conversion, large molecular catalytic conversion, or multifunctional sensors. Yang et al. prepared hollow-structured ZIF-8 by using a template method for generating a single-atom catalyst (HPC-800) (Fig. 11b). The resulting HPC-800 exhibited a high metal content (11.3 wt%) and a high specific surface area (895 m2·g−1), thereby providing rich active sites for catalytic reactions. The HPC-800 catalyst with hollow porous structure facilitated multiple reflections of light within its structure, creating favorable conditions for light utilization and photothermal conversion. Simultaneously, the atomic dispersion of Zn/N active sites ensured unfettered contact between reactants (epoxides and CO2). Consequently, the HPC-800 catalyst demonstrated exceptional performance in catalyzing the CO2 cycloaddition under light illumination and at ambient temperature [152]. 3.2.2 Other MOFs derived materials for CO2 cycloaddition reaction By integrating multifunctional components with MOFs in a rational way, MOFs-based catalysts can typically enhance the catalytic activity of specific reactions. As depicted in Fig. 12 , Chen et al. successfully synthesized graded porous MOFs (CN@MIL), through pyrolysis of ILs@MIL-101 composite precursor. The resulting composite material, CN@MIL, showcased an abundance of mesopores while maintaining structural stability. Moreover, CN@MIL possessed multiple active sites, enabling efficient mass transfer of substrates. As a result, CN@MIL demonstrated outstanding performance in CO2 cycloaddition reaction under mild and non-assisted conditions. Moreover, the multiple active sites, nucleophilic sites (Br−), and strong affinity of the catalyst for CO2 also make CN@MIL highly catalytically active. This method of preparing MOFs-based composite materials using ILs@MOFs as a precursor opens up a new path for developing advanced multiphase catalysts [153]. Furthermore, as shown in Table 2 , we also compared the performance of MOFs-derived catalysts with different structures in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction. From Table 2, the MOFs-based catalysts exhibit higher catalytic performance in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction, which can become a highly promising catalyst with great potential. 3.2.3 Research progress on cooperative catalysts When a catalyst contains two separate substances that both exhibit catalytic activity, the one with higher activity is the main catalyst while the one with lower activity is the cooperative catalyst. Combining the two can enhance catalytic activity. Meanwhile, auxiliary catalysts can improve the activity, selectivity, thermal stability, toxicity resistance, mechanical strength, and lifespan of the catalyst. MOFs are commonly recognized as heterogeneous catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition reaction. The MOFs with unsaturated metal sites could serve as Lewis acid sites, which may arise from secondary building units or functionalized organic ligands. However, these systems often necessitate the inclusion of Lewis basic auxiliary catalysts, such as tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB), to facilitate the opening step by attacking the carbon atoms in the epoxide. TBAB is chosen due to its ability to promote the opening step with minimal steric hindrance. But ammonium salts have high solubility in the reaction system, making it hard to recover the auxiliary catalyst from the reaction system. Furthermore, the presence of halide anions can lead to the corrosion of iron metals, thereby posing limitations on large-scale industrial applications to some extent. To overcome this problem, other auxiliary catalysts, as well as the interaction modes between auxiliary and main catalysts, have been developed. Among many of these auxiliary catalysts, ILs show potential. ILs composed of organic cations (e.g. quaternary ammonium salts and quaternary phosphonium salts, halide and tetrafluoroborate ions [129,154,155]), are of salts characterized by their ability to remain in a liquid state at room temperature, consisting solely of cations and anions. These anions are often Lewis bases that can be modified within the framework structure of MOFs to promote CO2 ring-opening reactions. Jiang et al. used a simple bottle-in-ship technique to prepare a highly efficient and reusable catalyst (Mim-6@MIL-101) (Fig. 13a ). The composite catalyst Mim-6@MIL-101 possesses abundant open metal sites as well as multiple active nucleophilic anion sites. On top of that, the high surface area (1162 m2·g−1) and strong affinity for CO2 molecules enable it to be a promising catalyst for CO2 cycloaddition reaction. Taking advantage of these features, a propylene carbonate yield of 93% was achieved (100°C, 1.0 MPa, and 2.5 h), without the need for auxiliary catalysts or additional solvents. Additionally, the Mim-6@MIL-101 exhibits the ability to be recycled up to three times without experiencing a significant decrease in catalytic activity [156]. The bottle-in-ships technique can be extended to the preparation of ILs-encapsulated porous frameworks, and both ILs and MOFs catalysts hold great promising in CO2 cycloaddition reaction. The encapsulation of catalysts can introduce various challenges that impact their overall catalytic performance, such as pore blocking, restricted diffusion, low stability, and the inevitable coverage of active sites. These factors inevitably lead to a reduction in the catalyst's efficiency. To address this, Xu et al. initially synthesized the MOFs precursor MIL-101-NH2 through a hydrothermal synthesis method. They then coupled it with aldehyde ketone condensation and N(BzBnme2)Br ILs to synthesis of MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br composite (Fig. 13b). The coordination interaction between unsaturated Cr3+ ions and Br− anions in MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br leads to its significant performance (93% yield and 99% selectivity) in the CO2 cycloaddition reaction under the certain reaction conditions (1.4 MPa CO2, 100°C, and 5 h reaction time). Additionally, the MIL-101-N(Bnme2)Br can be easily recovered through filtration, reused multiple times, and maintains its activity without significant degradation [157]. Liu et al. discovered that the catalytic performance of imidazolium-based ILs varies depending on the length of the carbon chain. This phenomenon arises due to the fact that shorter carbon chains result in lower activity, which further reduces in electron-donating ability of the nitrogen atom and electron density of the Br− anion. Conversely, longer carbon chains reduce the pore size of the catalyst, leading to steric hindrance and decreased catalytic activity [158]. Dai et al. grafted a quaternary phosphonium salt ILs ([BuPh3P]Br) onto Cr-MIL-101-NH2 to create a novel type of MOFs, Cr-MIL-101-[BuPh3P]Br (Fig. 13c). This introduction of the quaternary phosphonium salt ionic liquid notably enhanced the performance and stability of Cr-MIL-101-[BuPh3P]Br catalyst during the catalytic process [61]. 3.2.4 The economic benefits and potential industrial applications of MOFs materials in CO2 cycloaddition Currently, the lack of efficient methods for mass producing MOFs significantly impedes the industrialization process of these materials. Academic research conducted in laboratories typically only yields milligram-scale quantities of MOFs, which deviates greatly from the requirements of industrial production. Scalable and cost-effective production methods have not been widely studied and are often restricted to specific types of MOFs materials. Furthermore, the majority of MOFs-based materials are in a powdered form, which limits their practical applications. Powdered MOFs materials are challenging to handle and often necessitate expensive and time-consuming techniques, such as centrifugation. Moreover, the use of these materials presents inherent safety concerns, such as respiratory health risks. The downstream processing of MOFs powders into usable products is minimal when compared to other industries, as there is little impetus in the academic community to develop commercially viable products. Consequently, this situation creates a substantial disparity between the potential of MOFs materials in addressing practical problems and their economic and industrial prospects. Thus, evaluating the economic and industrial application value of MOFs materials in CO2 cycloaddition reactions can only be approached from a potential perspective [159]. The industrialization of MOFs in the direction of CO2 cycloaddition has enormous potential. Because the CO2 is a common greenhouse gas, and its emissions have significant impacts on global climate change. Therefore, utilizing CO2 for environmentally friendly chemical transformations is of great significance. MOFs, as a type of porous material, possesses high tunability and surface activity, which makes them suitable for catalyzing CO2 cycloaddition reactions. In the CO2 cycloaddition reaction, CO2 reacts with other organic compounds to form useful compounds such as organic carbonates. The porous structure of MOFs provides abundant active sites and large surface area, facilitating catalytic reactions. Currently, some studies have reported successful cases of using MOFs for CO2 cycloaddition reactions. These studies have demonstrated that MOFs exhibit good catalytic activity, high selectivity, and stability in catalyzing CO2 cycloaddition reactions. However, there are still challenges to be addressed in order to achieve the industrialization of MOFs in CO2 cycloaddition. Firstly, it is necessary to further improve the catalytic activity and stability of MOFs to meet the requirements of industrial applications. Secondly, process optimization and scale-up production need to be considered for catalytic reactions. Additionally, environmental and economic feasibility issues such as wastewater treatment and catalyst recovery need to be addressed. Despite these challenges, the industrialization of MOFs in CO2 cycloaddition remains a promising and hopeful direction. With technological advancements and further research, it is believed that more significant breakthroughs will be achieved to promote the industrial application in this field. This will contribute to the reduction of CO2 emissions and promote environmental sustainability. Therefore, these advantages of MOFs materials guide us in the direction of developing new materials without the need to rely on expensive production costs to develop new CO2 activation and conversion materials, which also helps save research and development costs to some extent [159,160]. 4 Conclusion and Outlook In conclusion, MOFs have emerged as a prominent catalyst for CO2 cycloaddition reaction. Moreover, certain types of MOFs, particularly derivatives obtained through pyrolysis, have demonstrated remarkable performance in the photocatalysis of this reaction. However, these catalysts still need to overcome many challenges, mainly including obtaining ideal conversion rates and yields under mild reaction conditions, and achieving good conversion of more challenging epoxides. Multi-metallic MOFs and/or MOFs with multi-site post-modification, together with a small amount of co-catalysts, sometimes without co-catalysts, can complete the reaction in a synergistic way, but the effect of these catalysts is difficult to compare with the catalytic system with a large amount of co-catalysts added. Efforts should be made to enhance the sustainability of these catalytic systems by eliminating the use of toxic and non-recyclable solvents. These types of catalysts will continue to be utilized and further studied in the field of CO2 conversion in the future. coredata.dc:description: The combustion of fossil fuels leads to the significant emission of carbonaceous compounds (e.g. CO2, CO), which results in a range of environmental problems (e.g. global warming). Among numerous carbonaceous compounds, although CO2 is the main culprit causing greenhouse effect, it is also an important carbon resource that can be used as a raw material for the synthesis of other important chemical substances. Among numerous CO2 activation and conversion processes, CO2 cycloaddition is an economically efficient transformation method because of its low price of raw materials, no other by-products during the reaction process, and atomic utilization rate of up to 100%, which comply with "green chemistry" and "atom economy". Moreover, the products of cyclic carbonates (e.g. ethylene carbonate, propylene carbonate) play a crucial role in the electric vehicle industry and are widely utilized for their numerous advantages. However, CO2 is inert and difficult to be activated, so the search for efficient and stable catalysts is crucial for the rapid CO2 conversion. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as highly promising materials in the field of CO2 activation and conversion due to their tremendous potential for development. This review provides a comprehensive analysis of the application of MOFs based catalysts in CO2 conversion. In addition, this study explores potential techniques for enhancing the catalytic efficiency of novel catalysts based on MOFs while investigating unexplored reactions for CO2 conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Recent research progress of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) based catalysts for CO2 cycloaddition reaction
